0670033375|1.0|Dr. Diamond is one of those academic sluts who come up with a theory before he ever bothers with observation or hypothesis.  So what you have here is a piece of pop culture pseudo science that a lot of people who know NOTHING about archeology, archeo-botany or climate theory are going to believe because this guy has a PhD. (You know what that PhD stands for?  Piled Higher and Deeper.  And in this case, it applies.) <br /> <br />He started this book with a point to prove, and then went out and found his \\"case studies\\" to fit his theory, entirely ignoring the little matter of the professional standard of scientific theory, which requires both observation and hypothesis AS A STARTING POINT.  Along the way, he entirely ignores whole libraries of both physical evidence and documentary information that disagree with his pre-determined viewpoint.   <br /> <br />His case studies--particularly the Easter Island one--are based in RACIST anthropological models that presume that the 'civilizations' in question were just plain stupid.  Of course, he being the Smart White Professor at the California University can help us avoid these poor, misguided, simpleton's mistakes, because, of course, we are White People.  <br /> <br />There's a reason that this book wasn't published by a University press--it could NEVER have gotten past peer review.  There are just too many assumptions, most of them false and racially biased, and there are reams of documentary evidence to prove him wrong.   <br /> <br />But peer-review standards and accurate scholarship don't mean anything to Viking, nor to the average eco-fan.  <br /> <br />The thing that really chaps me is that people are going to buy this thing, and because he can manage to string 2 sentencess together in a row, they're going to buy the argument, even though when all is said and done, the most CHARITABLE evaluation of it would be to call his interpretation a misrepresentation.   <br /> <br />Personally, I call it Lying By Omission.  Leave out the facts you don't like, pretend they don't exist, and you'll sell half a million books to people who don't have the background to know that you're only telling about 25% of the story.   <br /> <br />That's the real story of Diamond's book--how to hoodwink the eco-movement in 600 pages and make a million while you're at it.  <br /> <br />
B00005JNTX|4.0|Sin City is a visually striking film. It fully succeeds in capturing the feel of the graphic novel it is based on and of Film Noir in general. The acting is also good, within the limitations of the comic book-style chosen by the film-maker. The interlinked stories are well told. Some of the comments of previous reviewers are, however, puzzling. For example, in a film which is filled with eye-gouging, torture, mutilations, and amputations, not a few reviewers found time to comment on the \\"graphic nudity\\", which consisted of a couple of brief, shadowy shots of breasts. One aspect of American Culture I have always found puzzling is the propensity to view the most ghastly and sadistic forms of violence as \\"good wholesome entertainment\\" while a glimpse of an exposed nipple on television sends the whole nation into hysterics. Don't get me wrong, I love this country, but that is a bit of a paradox. A second odd comment I've seen concerns the supposed mysogyny of this film. Yes, most of the female characters are prostitutes, but the film is about the underbelly of society. Most of these women are portrayed as intelligent, strong, and perfectly capable of defending themselves. They are actually shown in a far more positive light than any of the male characters, who are almost universally portrayed as brutal, sadistic cavemen who are apparently obsessed with attacking other men's genitals. If anything, the film is more anti-male (mysandrous?) than mysogynistic.

B00007FOMP|5.0|Often referred to as the greatest soul album of all time, \\"What's Going On\\" was not only Gaye's magnum opus, it was also the most important record he had ever released. Needless to say, it was far different from the Motown hit machine of the time. Gaye went from R&B sex symbol to a true recording artist with the release of \\"What's Going On\\", and was rightly hailed as one of pop music's best and most important artists. There is a concept to the album. From the viewpoint of his brother Frankie, a Vietnam vet (returned in 1967), the phrase \\"What's Going On\\" was not only a question of a distraught soldier returning from war (there's a reason why their isn't a question mark), it was to educate the listener on urban deterioration, police brutality, drug addiction, poverty, riots, and abandoned children among many other topical concerns. These performances were among Gaye's  most creative and ambitious. \\"What's Going On\\", \\"Save the Children\\", \\"Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology)\\", \\"Right On\\", and \\"Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)\\" are notable cuts, even though the album is best as a single listen. This is the first Soul/R&B album I've ever bought, and I cannot imagine a more perfect introduction to Gaye or the genre as a whole. Essential listening for any collection. Highly recommended.

B000002ADT|5.0|Often referred to as the best selling classic jazz album of all time, \\"Kind Of Blue\\" towers above Davis' peers on an epic level. This album simply set the standards for excellence, that no artist has ever been able to top. Why is it so perfect? I'm not 100% sure. Maybe it's because it never feels intimidating. Maybe because it captivates listeners by slowly inching it's way to instrumental highs and woes on a multitude of levels. The music is relaxed and easy to follow, yet it reveals more genius with each and every listen. Maybe because the music doesn't feel confined to a set of standard rules, because the whole set is improvised (per the liner notes by Bill Evans). Or maybe people come back to this record consistently, simply because it captures the most exceptional band in jazz history - Miles, Coltrane, Bill Evans, Cannonball Adderley, Paul Chambers, Jimmy Cobb. \\"Kind Of Blue\\" is the apex of tonal-jazz.<br /><br />I won't waste my time listing standout tracks, because I'd end up picking out the entire album. The fact that this music works as background and mood music, but also works on a level of close listening, is one of the reasons it's my favorite. Trust me, no jazz enthusiast is missing this album in their collection. It's simply the cornerstone of \\"any\\" jazz collection.

B000B5XOY8|4.0|Tim Burton pulled much from Frank Miller's Dark Knight Returns to create the hard visuals for his Gotham City.  Frank Miller was the writer credited with darkening the hell out of the Dark Knight. In this film, Batman and the Joker are given almost equal screen time and have interlocking origins.  It was a very interesting concept and many actually prefer this origin for the Joker to the comic version where he's a nice stand up comic who gets involved with the mob but really doesn't want to. He's much better as a character who was always ready to terrorize. Many people who didn't pay attention to the film can come away with thinking the Joker has more screen time and that Batman doesn't get enough. These people obviously haven't paid attention: the Joker has more LINES because he's the Joker, Batman has less lines because Batman doesn't need to talk very much (see Batman Forever and Batman and Robin for good examples of what happens when Batman talks to much, you get crap). The film follows Batman/Bruce and we get to see how awkward it is for him to maintain basic human relationships as he tries to deal with his own baggage and save an entire city from the Joker's rampage. This is an excellent film from director Tim Burton, despite a lot of studio interferance like adding Prince, something Burton fought to get removed but, obviously, no dice. This film, like the Frank MIller comics he drew from, set a new tone for Batman in the public eye. A darker Batman.  Even though Nolan's Batman Begins was far closer to Batman's actual origins and demeanor fromt he comics, Burton's film is still very good as a sort of Elseworlds tale.

B000B5XOSO|4.0|Batman Returns features the best film dipiction of Gotham City to date. The city is grim, always dark, even during the day, old gothic spires stab at the sky.  This is Gotham the way it was intended: a dark pseudo 1800's looking city with a flare for 1940's decor.  In this film, Burton once again weaves Batman's story into the lives of his villians, shown through Bruce/Batman's relationship with Selina Kyle/Catwoman.  Burton did something most writers simply do not do: develop the villains.  We witness both Selina's tragic transformation to Catwoman, and the origins of the deformed Penguin.  In the comics, these characters were barely ever fleshed out, save for Frank Miller's Batman Year One, where he showed the beginnings of Catwoman as a dominatrix for hire, something to this day that DC would like to keep under the rug.  In this film, Batman and Catwoman have a tremendously complex relationship.  Batman this time around is far more in control of things, has a more streamlined and expanded batcave, and barely speaks while in the suit, all showing a more dead on version of Batman, the efficient strong, silent type hero.  A lot of people critiqued this film as \\"not a kids movie\\" but I always wonder, who says Batman is a kids character in the first place besides Adam West? The comics of Batman nowadays are no where near kid friendly, his villians are darker, more twisted, he's had side kicks brutally murdered, tortured to death, and crippled.  Not to mention that the whole story starts off with an eight year old boy's parents getting brutally murdered before his very eyes. yeah, shame on Burton for not making that all kid friendly... anyway, this film is an artistic masterpiece and set the tone for the aminated series which tried very hard to model itself after the Burton films, even going so far as to get the films composer, Danny Elfman, to do the cartoons theme.  Burton realized that Batman's villains should be just as messed up psychologically as he is, and as such, should be given equal screen time and character development, something they didn't really start doing in the comics until about eight years ago, in the late 90's.  Before that, they were just cardboard cut outs save for a few stories from Alan Moore and Frank Miller.  Batman Returns has a constant theme of wearing masks socially, persoanlly, and in all other aspects of life, Burton shows what happens when those masks are torn away and people are forced to face their own dark secrets.

B00003CXCT|5.0|In 1977, George Lucas began crafting a series of movies that would shape the way modern cinema was made for generations to come.  That series was none other than the 'Star Wars' saga, though he began his saga in 1977, the first movie was actually the middle chapter in a 6-part story.  After the success of \\"Star Wars - Episode 4: A New Hope\\" (then it was known only as \\"Star Wars\\"), George Lucas crafted the final 2 chapters in his epic space saga, \\"Star Wars - Episode 5: The Empire Strikes Back\\" and \\"Star Wars - Episode 6: Return of the Jedi\\".  Upon completion of 'Episode 6', George took a hiatus from the grand universe he'd created, a hiatus that would last over 25 years, and would leave fans foaming at the mouth with anticipation.  During the mid-nineties there were rumors abound that George was working on the first 3 chapters of his space saga, a rumor that was further fueled by the 1997 theatrical re-release of the original trilogy with new CGI effects and scenes added in.  Finally in 1999, the time had arrived for the unveiling of the first chapter of the 'Star Wars' saga with, \\"Star Wars - Episode 1: The Phantom Menace\\".  Three years later he released \\"Star Wars - Episode 2: Attack of the Clones\\", and in 2005 George Lucas brought his series full circle with the much acclaimed, \\"Star Wars - Episode 3: Revenge of the Sith\\".  I have already reviewed the 3 films that comprise what is known as the prequel trilogy, and now it is time for me to finish my series of reviews based on the 'Star Wars' movies with my review of the box set of the original trilogy.  The following will be a synopsis of the basic plotline for each of the 3 films from the original trilogy, followed by the overall review of the box set.  If you are already familiar with the stories for this series, then feel free to skip the next 3 paragraphs, for those of you that may have been living under a stone for the last 25 years, continue reading the next 3 paragraphs. <br /> <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 4:A New Hope\\" takes place approximately 16-20 years after the events of 'Episode 3'.  The galaxy is in turmoil under the iron fist rule of Emperor Palpatine and his Dark Lord of the Sith, Darth Vader, who together are in complete control of the evil Empire.  Their are very few heroes left in the galaxy, with almost all of the Jedi exterminated during the 'Jedi Purge' that was perpetrated by Darth Vader, all that remains of the former glory of the Republic is a growing group of rebels that hope to one day bring down the evil reign of the Empire.  Assisting the Rebellion, led by an ambitious Princess from Alderaan, named Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher), are an old man, who just so happens to be former Jedi Master Obi-Wan Kenobi, a young farm boy from Tatooine, Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), and a space pirate named Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and his Wookie companion, Chewbacca.  Together this rag-tag group of unlikely heroes hope to bring down the Empire's newest weapon, the planet destroying 'Death Star', and the key to this mission rests in the most unlikely of places, with that of 2 droids, C-3PO and R2-D2. <br /> <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 5: The Empire Strikes Back\\" picks up about 5 years after 'Episode 4'.  The 'Death Star' has been destroyed by Luke Skywalker, the Rebellion seemed to be on the upswing, but luck would not last forever, as the rebels have been forced to flee yet again to the ice planet of Hoth.  Luke and Han have become formidable pilots for the Rebellion, though Han and Chewie are looking to leave in order to pay off a bounty on Han's head, and Luke continues to strive to learn more about the Force, though his mentor and guide Obi-Wan Kenobi was killed at the hands of Darth Vader.  For Luke to learn what he must to become a Jedi, and assist the Rebellion in overthrowing the darkness that is ruling the galaxy, Obi-Wan appears as a 'Force Spirit' to Luke and instructs him to seek out an old Jedi Master named Yoda who has exiled himself to a swamp planetcalled Dagobah.  Will Luke be able to become the Jedi he is destined to be, or is it too late to hope for the galaxy? <br /> <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 6: Return of the Jedi\\" takes place a few months after 'Episode 5', as Luke, Leia, Lando, and Chewbacca are planning to free their captured comrade Han Solo from his Carbonite prison and from the clutches of the vile, sluggish-gangster, Jabba the Hutt.  Once freed can Han and his friends in the Rebellion manage to destroy the currently under construction 'Death Star 2' that is being personally overseen by Darth Vader and his master, Emperor Palpatine.  Will Luke become a true Jedi Knight, and lead the galaxy out of it's darkness that has bound it for so long, or will he succumb to his anger, and embrace the legacy laid out by his father, Anakin Skywalker, by becoming a Dark Jedi?  The fate of the galaxy hangs in the balance. <br /> <br />The 'Star Wars' saga has been by far one of the most influential film series' ever created, and after viewing the entire 6-part saga all together, it really comes as no surprise.  With groundbreaking special effects, and leading the way from film to Digital media, the 'Star Wars' saga has paved the way for how many films are created today in this modern age of cinema.  The 'Star Wars' saga has something for everyone in the family to enjoy, from it's epic 6-part story, to it's awe-inspiring battles and space flights, with some comedy and romance thrown in for good measure.  This series is not one to be missed, and without a doubt is one of the greatest movie series' of all time! <br /> <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 4: A New Hope\\" is rated PG for violence. <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 5: The Empire Strikes Back\\" is rated PG for violence. <br />\\"Star Wars - Episode 6: Return of the Jedi\\" is rated PG for violence.

B000006O7C|4.0|Jeff Buckley, perhaps the most talented singer of his generation, never finished his second album.  Tentatively titled \\"My Sweetheart the Drunk\\", Buckley had recorded an album's worth of material with producer Tom Verlaine before deciding he was unhappy with it and headed to Memphis to work up some demos.  While in Memphis, Buckley drowned in a swimming accident and would never complete the album.  As time has passed, his estate (run primarily by his mother Mary Guibert) decided to release the recordings he had been working on-- with the verlaine sessions on one CD and the followup work on another.  No attempt at retroactively completing them was done, and as such, the material (particularly the second disc) has a somewhat rough feel to it.  As it is incomplete, the release was titled \\"Sketches for My Sweetheart the Drunk\\". <br /> <br />Listening to the Verlaine sessions, the choice to abandon them makes little sense.  Admittedly, it's not quite as good as \\"Grace\\", but it's not done either, and it is awfully good as is.  It feels like a sort of less bombastic version of \\"Grace\\", with Buckley exploring his mid-range tenor in more detail and experimenting in vocal harmonies and jangly guitar parts.  The music explores a soul sound (\\"Everybody Here Wants You\\", with one of the best falsetto deliveries Buckley ever did), Buckley's lower register (\\"Nightmares By the Sea\\"), alt-rock (\\"Yard of BLonde Girls\\") and the most avant-garde work Buckley ever did (the unclassifiably brilliant \\"New Year's Prayer\\").  And quite frankly, there's not a bad track on the disc. <br /> <br />The second disc finds Buckley searching-- be it for a musical direction or a vocal range to sing in-- check fractured avant-garde blues \\"Demon John\\" for examples of both.  Buckley sings in as low a register as he ever has over a bizarre, churning alternative riff that hints at psychedelia and blues and noise and really is uncategorizably his own.  Likewise, his superb cover of Genesis' \\"Back in N.Y.C.\\" is something to hear-- running arhythmically and feeling more like a free association than a song, it somehow works magnificently.  And while other cuts aren't quite as successfull (most notably psychedelic dirge \\"Murder Suicide Meteor Slave\\"), certainly the material is intriguing, and one wonders where it would have ended up. <br /> <br />The liner notes contain two essays-- one by Bill Flanagan describing the context into which these recordings were both recorded and released, and one by  Mary Guibert talking of her decision to release these. <br /> <br />In all, it's a good recording, it's not \\"Grace\\", it's not complete enough to be \\"Grace\\", and it feels like a love letter to the fans rather than a real release.  Newcomers to Buckley should start with \\"Grace\\", the initiated will want this as well.

B0002S94BG|5.0|Jeff Buckley's \\"Grace\\" is one of those albums. One of those life-changing records that the first time you hear it (and I mean REALLY hear it-- it took me over ten years to really hear it), you stop what you're doing, no matter what, and you just listen. And somehow, when its done, you start it over again and it feels like everything's changed. <br /> <br />Buckley, who died at a young age after recording only one studio album (this one), has left a legacy with us. Showing signs of his pedigree in downtown New York, his music has that sort of unnamed quality you can't quite pin down. Simple folk songs or delicate blues somehow become quite a bit more. It could be Buckley's voice, a high tenor that feels a bit like a non-tempered instrument, is certainly evocative and filled with emotion. It could be the subtlety of the arrangements. It could be something else entirely. <br /> <br />The point is, its there, and the music really is transcendent. To single out any particular track is a bit unfair, its pretty much all unbelievably good, from blues-based rock (\\"Mojo Pin\\", \\"Eternal Life\\") to ballads (\\"Hallelujah\\", \\"Lilac Wine\\", \\"Corpus Christi Carol\\") and some material that just defies even such broad categories (\\"Last Goodbye\\", \\"So Real\\"). But really, star to finish, a superb record. <br /> <br />The Legacy Edition has been newly remastered, admittedly probably somewhat unnecessary given that the album is only a decade or so old, but noentheless the sound is crisp and clean.  The bonus disc includes a dozen or so tracks, b-sides, alternate versions, and so on.  The material isn't quite as essential as the album, but it's all awfully good, and certainly several of the tracks are as strong as the material on \\"Grace\\" (\\"Forget Her\\", \\"Mama, You Been on My Mind\\").  The set also contains a DVD with a \\"Making of Grace\\" documentary filmed in the '90s and updated for this set that is quite an interesting watch and runs about 30 minutes long.  Buckley's band in particular is a treatto hear interviewed.  The disc is also augmented by the videos for the album's singles.  Finally, the liner notes contain commentary about all the bonus tracks by producer Steve Berkowitz and Mary Guibert (Jeff Buckley's mother) and a brief essay on \\"A Decade of Grace\\" by Bill Flanagan.  All of this comes wrapped in a giant digipack and a plastic slipcase.  All in all, it looks quite nice (and it matches \\"Live at Sin-E\\" well too-- now if only \\"My Sweetheart the Drunk\\" would get this treatment!). <br /> <br />All in all, this is one great value, and a nice way at looking at the legacy of what really is one of the best albums of its decade.  Highly recommended.

Good books, just much different in tone than Ender's Game. <br /> <br />

B000059QYB|4.0|During the 80's, Billy Idol was a commercial force to be reckoned with, releasing a series of tracks that seemed to fit in perfectly with the New-Wave & Album Rock radio orientated tracks, that seemed to make up a large part of the commercial music charts.  Mixing a punk attitude with the catchy hooks of rock, and the accessibility of Pop, he had a series of singles that frequently entered the singles chart in the U.S. (with some small success in the U.K.), and such was his ubiquity, that several tracks made their way onto a fair few American 80's films, and music compilations. <br /> <br />His was a sound that successfully mixed a confident swagger, with the rowdy and brash bravado of his more Punk-rock orientated tracks (\\"Rebel Yell\\", \\"Mony Mony\\"), alongside more theatrical and stylish New Wave/Pop crossover songs (\\"Dancing with Myself\\", \\"Sweet Sixteen\\", \\"Hot in the City\\"), and always clever enough to remember that at least one anthemic ballad should be included on every album (\\"White Wedding\\", \\"Eyes Without a Face\\").  And as the record companies have noticed that the new current bands these days, are frequently referencing 80's music in their songs, (or indeed 80's act's rejoining), that the timing is perfect for a compilation that highlights the best tracks from one of the 80's biggest hitters.  <br /> <br />Billy Idol's career didn't really revolve around albums, (he wasnt much of a album artist), and instead, was a much more potent force as a singles artist.  And it's here that the compilation purely concentrates on, offering a short, sharp & sweet culmination of his career, in a compilation that pretty much includes all the essential singles, that document his career.  And Unlike a lot of the other 80's artists that you may have had a fondness for, Billy's music has dated incredibly well.  For proof of this, stick on \\"Hot in the City\\", \\"Eyes Without a Face\\" or \\"Dancing with myself\\" to hear a sound that is quite clearly 80's in sound and instrumentation, yet still has that emotional attachment/connection that it had the first time around.  Maybe this is due to the fact that some of these singles are still in rotation to some degree, in various forms of media/Music.  And so, maybe this means that we never truly got a chance to forget about them???  But what is clear, is that when listened to, they still contain the rebellious nature and appealing blend of pop hooks, punk attitude and rock bluster to hit all the right buttons.  And thankfully some care has been taken with the compiling of this compilation, as unless you are a die-hard fan, there isn't really anything noticeably missing here.  There is an live acoustic version of \\"Rebel Yell\\" on the last half of the album, and although it'll never replace the studio version (also on this disk), shows that Billy could deliver the goods, Live.  (although it probably would have worked better, being stuck as the last track on the compilation, rather than second from last).  And my only real compliant would be that one of my favourite tracks \\"Don't you (Forget about me)\\", is a newly recorded version. Why???.....the original was utterly sublime, and although this new recorded version is still excellent, you can hear that it's ever so slightly more uptempo than the original, and remains slightly inferior to the original version. <br /> <br />But that is a small point, and its surprising, just how well his works stands up, after digging this superb compilation out and listening to it, some 4 years since the last time it heard it.  If you (Like me), just want a compilation of all the hits without having to dip into the studio albums, you really should make this the only Billy Idol purchase you'll need.  It is arguably the finest of the small amount of compilations that have been released for him, and will completely satisfy anyone, either new to, or looking to revisit his work.  highly recommended!!!
B00003W8NM|5.0|From the opening sequence traveling through the inner workings of Edward Norton's neural system it's clear that director David Fincher wants to assault your senses with 'Fight Club'. He throws in everything including a few kitchen sinks so that by the end of his film you'll want to take the ride again. He doesn't care that some aspects don't quite make that much sense or that the main character Tyler Durden has a viewpoint that some would call fasscist. He wants you to think about 'Fight Club'...but not until the last (and very vivid) frame is over. <br /> <br />Edward Norton plays Jack - a depressed business man stuck in a nine to five job and hating every second of his miserable existance. So much so that he cannot sleep a wink. He stumbles into the world of support groups (namely testicular cancer) and begins to feel better about himself; he is finally able to sleep. That is until a chain-smoking, pill-popper Marla comes in with the same plan of crashing support groups. His lie reflects his lie. After meeting an eccentric soap salesman by the name of Tyler Durden (Brad Pitt) the two decide to unleash their aggrevation with the world by beating each other up - and loving it. <br /> <br />From the opening scene Fight Club is full of ideas and principles and logic. Half-way through many of those ideas have either meshed together to form something greater or collided with a bang/thud - and still formed something more substantial. By the end of the film we're in chaos. The ideas still make sense but we're so immersed in the story of Jack and Tyler that we can't stop and think about all this logic. This is not a bad thing. In fact, it's a great thing.  <br /> <br />By the second half of the film you are no longer allowed to have a breath of fresh air. There are no moments of release where you will think that one character is going to be okay. David Fincher hands over the controls to Tyler Durden and we strap ourselves in.  <br /> <br />Fight Club is brilliant and the critics never gave it the respect it deserved. Not only is the film full of ideas, but it's extremely well acted by the entire cast, offers some breathtaking imagery (much of which is CGI but rarely noticeable), and startling and frank scenes of violence and uncontrolled mayhem. In many films that would be a detractor; Fight Club goes overboard with every element but at the same time manages to pull it off perfectly. Kudos to David Fincher for assaulting us - nobody could have done it so well.

B00005OMTT|5.0|Ah. Enigma. Savor the word. Feel it flow off your tongue. Rarely does a musician choose such a captivating alias, yet alone one that so perfectly describes the intricate music laying underneath. With this greatest hits release Love Sensuality Devotion we are taken into the mysterious world of Michael Cretu, via 18 sensational tracks laced with beauty and rinsed in atmosphere. Think of a beautiful painting, the kind that forces you to stare for minutes on end. Now imagine this painting being transformed into a song, and you should have some sort of idea as what to expect from this mastermind. Mixing dancepop beats with Gregorian chants, a diverse range of synths, and gorgeous female vocals placed here and there, Cretu never hides his love for artistic experimentation - which makes Enigma's success all the more interesting, given all the tasteless musical trends that have emerged over the past decade and a half. Perhaps it's that such hits as \\"Return to Innocence\\" and \\"Sadeness Pt. 1\\" are just so darn addictive. Who knows? But why complain?  <br /> <br />Production-wise, the album fails on no level. It is obvious which songs have been remastered and which have been left untampered with, but they all sound great in the long run. From the calm tenderness of \\"Shadows in Silence\\" to the catchy atmo-synth of \\"TNT for the Brain\\", you will be left speechlessly dazed and entranced (especially after multiple listens, which are required for full musical comprehension). Other hits like the epic \\"I Love You...I'll Kill You\\" complete with blaring guitars, or the infectious \\"Turn Around\\" - a song exclusively written for this record - are also essentials. My personal favorite track is number 3, \\"Gravity of Love\\", fronted by angelic female singing, rounded out by an ethereal chorus and some rather enchanting operatic vocals. Actually, since there are no weak tracks to be found, the album flows pretty darn well too - a big plus in my book, especially for \\"best of\\" releases which are often muddled by poor organization.  <br /> <br />In conclusion, LSD is an essential, comprised of pure new age classics, fit for any and all CD collections built on the foundation of good music (aka music with substance). Don't let yourself miss out on such an incredible masterpiece - you'd only be mistreating yourself. Don't believe me? Well, I'll sum this CD up in three words - find, grab, buy!  <br /> <br />10/10 <br /> <br />[Originally written August 1, 2005]

0930289528|2.0|Cliche, predictable, lifeless and boring are just the obvious adjectives that come to mind when I think of V for Vendetta. Maybe it wouldn't seem so dull had 1984 never been written. In that case I might find it more inspiring and exciting. But the fact that Orwell was such a master of his craft and painted a much more intriguing vision of a totalitarian future than Moore could accomplish even with the aid of actual illustration just makes V look childish. <br /> <br />I had heard nothing but praise for this book, and was utterly disappointed. I've been reading that the movie version (the trailer for which is what sparked my interest to begin with) is not all too faithful to the actual comic, and I can only hope that this is true. Hopefully the Wachowski brothers re-vamped and pumped some much-needed life into this story. <br /> <br />If you really want to read a comic that contains a brilliant and truly thoughtful story, I suggest either of Frank Miller's masterpieces Batman: The Dark Knight Returns or Batman: Year One.

B000059MEK|1.0|Interesting that the two French DJs known as Daft Punk would imitate robots, because their music is as mindless and repetitive as something that would come from an automaton.    I've listened to a lot of bad albums, but Discovery stands out as one the most uniquely unpleasant listening experience I've ever had the misfortune of enduring. Not being satisfied with one listen, I instead subjected myself to the entire CD's length at least three times in the vain hope that it would somehow grow on me. Quite the opposite, as I found myself despising it with a greater and greater passion with every listen.    Can one honestly tell me that any effort was put into this CD when nearly every track is repetitive and cylical to a downright ludicrous degree? With the exception of \\"Digital Love\\" (the only halfway decent song on the album), each and every song consists of a single hook looped fifty to a hundred times over a simple beat for nearly the entire length of the song. Tracks go nowhere, build to nothing, and only if you're very lucky will they ever change at all. Take \\"Superheroes\\" for example, where a single vocal sample repeats for nearly three quarters of the song's duration. This wouldn't be so bad (at least, not nearly as unbearable) if the songs were at least somewhat catchy, but they're not. There's nothing remotely memorable, and at a later time I had difficulty remembering anything about any of the songs. This isn't minimalism; this is music at its most lazy and uncreative. The only circumstance in which the songs on Discovery would be remotely listenable would be if I were high out of my mind, and even then that would be doubtful.    As if maddening repetition were not enough, Discovery is replete with irritating synth samples that sound like they were dredged out of the worst of 80's synth-pop. Vocoder vocals are used throughout, and only create further irritation and disgust. The whole album comes off as sickeningly cheesy and unaware of it. If Daft Punk had conceived this album as a mockery of Dance and House music, it would be a downright brilliant satire. More cynically, Discovery sounds like it was tailor-made for television commercials; each song containing just enough material for a half-minute jingle, and repeated over and over to stretch it out to a full album.    Your tastes might vary from mine, but I don't recall ever disliking an album as much as this one. Most bad music makes me feel either disappointment or boredom, but Daft Punk's Discovery is the first to inspire outright loathing and disgust. To my amazement, I have heard that Daft Punk's latest album \\"Human After All\\" is even more repetitive in nature than this.    How is that even possible?

0140441409|5.0|Although this book is the only translation that I have read on Marcus Aurelius's Mediations and do not have another example for comparison, this particular book has been a favorite and read many times.  Meditations is a timeless record of Stoic philosophy, not a religion as many people have misconceived; and therefore, this philosophy has historically received acceptance, and even, embracement.  With the heart of a warrior and the wisdom of a great leader, Aurelius shares how to weather the most difficult times, with grace and compassion.  His advice is practical and readers will identify with him on the common problems experienced by humans, and from his wisdom, learn how to apply his suggestions to our own times.  The introduction defines the Stoic Philosophy and devotes a brief section to the role that it played when the early Christian Church was formed.  Similiar to the Book of Proverbs style, it is possible to read one item every day for reflection.  This book is small enough to easily carry, and yet, the content is worth every penny of the book cost.

1573223026|5.0|I bought this book on impulse: the premise sounded a little different from the norm, the cover was a nice shade of blue, and I needed another purchase to reach the $25 free shipping total :) <br /> <br />I am very happy to report that it was money well spent.  <br /> <br />Nick Hornby brings together 4 very different characters, all with real problems in their lives, all about to take the plunge off the top of a tower block.. and yet his story is not dark and depressing.  <br /> Each of the four main characters take turns at telling parts of the story, which is an interesting writing technique - the reader discovers each character through the eyes of the 3 others, and also from their own ramblings. <br /> <br />Four complete strangers on the same roof, on the same night, contemplating the same fate - can they help each other? do they want to?   I won't give anything away, just take my word for it - this is a good little book.
0156027321|2.0|It's difficult to rate this book as just 2 stars.  The author, Mr. Martel, rightfully has received an outpouring of praise for his talent.  In fact, I felt a real psychological kinship with the author for many pages even beyond the first 100, which were so good. However, my 2-star rating reflects how I personally felt as a reader after finishing the book . . . very disappointed, misled and somewhat resentful that my time investment did not paying a bigger dividend.   <br /> <br />After the first 100 pages or so of excellence, the book gets TEDIOUS.  There's ocean drifting in extreme detail, with one trial after another that is ultimately irrelevant (at least to my small mind), except to make the reader appreciate the simultaneously boring, painful and trying nature of Pi's ocean voyage.  Still, it was overkill. <br /> <br />After the tedium, the book gets STUPID AND TEDIOUS. Pi encounters an acid algae island full of meerkats.  This development had two negative effects on me: first, there's the obvious tedium of reading someone's weird tales pulled out of thin air that seem to have little to do with the rest of the story (unless I want to put on a really heavy thinking cap and get creative like my old college English teachers--maybe then I could find some rationale for the Meerkat Island saga).  Second, the unapologetically fictitious nature of the Meerkat Island saga made me doubt certain interesting facts about animal behavior and swimming that Mr. Martel had weaved through the first part of the story.  Was any of that true?   <br /> <br />Yes, in retrospect, I can see where this was all leading.  I appreciate that one of the punch lines to this book is that truth is irrelevant in some sense.  But I felt then, and still do feel, a bit misled to have suspended disbelief enough to enjoy and thought I'd learned a thing or two from the first part the book only to be unable to trust any of it during the long remainder. <br /> <br />Having finished the Meerkat Algae Island saga, the book gets EVEN MORE \\"OUT THERE\\" AND TEDIOUS until Pi is interviewed by 2 men working for the Japanese Ministry of Transport.  This exchange was written quite tongue-in-cheek.  But think about what the reader has been through up until that point!  Tongue-in-cheek may have entertained the author, but I felt even less connected to the book than ever.  Though this is a fiction book, I craved a tone of reality and grounding. <br /> <br />And it's then-at that very point-that Mr. Martel gives us the \\"twist at the ending.\\"  As the reviews attest, many readers assumed this was reality and grounding.  I was tempted too.  As a reader invested at about 350 pages by then, I wanted to embrace the twist and say \\"this made it all worthwhile; now it all makes sense!\\"  But it didn't.  It didn't make sense because the new story (\\"twist\\") does not fit well with the original story.  It does in broad terms, but when I think back to details of the original story, the \\"twist\\" isn't congruent with many places-or at least not how I can see.   <br /> <br />Again, I know that the irrelevance of Truth is a big point of the book, so the sort out this fiction into something more \\"believeable\\" is beside the point intellectually--but readers have emotional needs too.   <br /> <br />Here's why truth and believeability are irrelevant in this book.  Pi asks the Japanses Minsitry investigators 2 versions of his terrible tragedy at sea and asks which they like better.  One has animals and is fantastic in the truest sense of the word.  The other is, to quote Pi, \\"a flat...dry, yeastless story.\\"  But is it really?  In that story, a man is \\"swinging his arms and catching flies and eating them greedily.\\"  Then this same big, nasty man who has done terrible things develops a conscience, thereby loses the will to live, and lets Pi kill him without a struggle?  That sounds like a real yarn-spinner story to me. <br /> <br />I suspect either bad writing here, or more likely, both stories (the mainbook plus the \\"twist ending\\") are unbelievable crocks.  Just as there's no discernibly True reason for the sinking of the ship ever found, I as a reader got no reasonable explanation for what happened to Pi at sea.  And that's okay, except I don't even get a good explanation of why I don't need a True explanation. <br /> <br />I only have theories: <br />***Pi may see investing stories as part of turning to God.  Although Pi mentions doing his prayers at sea, he only mentions turning to God after he kills someone in the second version of the story (p. 390 \\"I turned to God. I survived.\\").   <br /> <br />***Another reviewer did a nice job of summing up her take on Pi's view on religion and God.  Maybe she got it right.  Maybe Pi is saying there's no True God in the traditional sense, but only interesting and uninteresting stories (including those about God) that people either enjoy or do not enjoy.  Since the facts of life stay the same, and many religious claims are unproveable, is Pi saying one may as well pick the interesting stories you like that make reality more palatable?  Pick the religion(s) you wish? <br /> <br />***Another interpretation of Pi's perspective is that there is a God, but the stories describing for him--i.e., all the different religions--can't be validated as true or untrue sometimes and you just have to go with what story you like, and Pi likes them all.   <br /> <br />Maybe I am just not smart enough to see the ONE true message here that would make all my other criticisms pale by comparison.  If I were, maybe I'd have ended this book feeling good about what I'd read and not frustrated by little payoff for a long effort of reading.  Maybe I should call up some of my college English professors from 15 years ago so they can clear it up for me.  :-) <br />

0060536357|5.0|This book covers in depth the LBO of RJR Nabisco in the late 1980s. Recommended to me by an investment banker friend that knew I wanted to go into M&A work, I decided to read it. B0002IVN9W|4.0|The first song I heard off of this album was track #7, \\"Wake Up\\".  My reactions at the time were \\"wow, this sounds pretty special\\", then \\"actually, this is really good\\", to \\"man, this is kinda brilliant\\". <br /> <br />The same goes for the rest of the album.  There is tremendous energy, intelligence, and musicianship in this album.  What makes it really stand out from other contemporary bands is the instrumentation - sounds like there are about a gazillion instruments playing on each song.  While this could lead to a muddled/muffled type of over-inflated production for other bands, here it is absolutely gorgeous.  The sound is tremendously rich, with nothing superfluous. <br /> <br />Also, each track really stands out, and the melodies/chord structures are all at once simple, catchy, and original.  Very very high quality pop. <br /> <br />Why only four stars?  Very honestly, the lyrics lose me a bit.  Don't get me wrong, lyrically the album is fascinating, and clearly carries a number of themes throughout the record.  Two things bother me a little bit: (i) the lyrics are a bit too personal, and incomprehensibly baroque at first listen - you need to know about the bandmembers' history a bit to get them, and (ii) many of the lyrics are jarringly somber and melancholy, which doesn't seem to jive with the upbeat tempo of the songs.  As a result, the songs come across as a massive collaborative effort, but with perhaps more focus on the music (which sounds wonderfully organic) than the lyrics (which sound like one or two person wrote all of them and then forgot about them when the music was being composed).  Also (but this is a small point): elocution.  Difficult to understand what they're singing without the booklet at hand. <br /> <br />These are pretty minor drawbacks, though.  Overall, very highly recommended: it's moving, fun, and haunting music.  You'll be listening to it for a long time.

Every single song on his debut album was skillfully laced with funky rythms that would make Bootsy Collins and George Clinton proud and consisted of a young and energetic Snoop along with the rest of the crew to make that album a classic.  2001 is good and is one of the best produced albums of the past 6 years, and when the songs hit hard here, they're hitting real hard.  \\"Xxplosive\\" is a classic that is a little underated, mostly because Dre isn't on it, with a great verses from Kurupt and Nate Dogg.  Of course there are the commercial tracks \\"Still...\\" and \\"Forgot...,\\" but don't be fooled, these tracks are only the tip of the ice burg, from a production standpoint.  The raps by several B-artists bring this album down a little and the gangsta lyrics that were new and innovative in the early 90's seem to be worn out here, but what would a Dre album be without gangsta raps.  All in all, this a good album that was released at a time when rap most needed it, but if you don't own THE CHRONIC, I strongly recommend that album to see the Good Dr. at his best.

B00005JMAH|4.0|This movie is definitely darker than the first two.  It didn't do as well at the box office, but I think there are two reasons for that:  (a) The people who liked the first two movies probably went away a bit disappointed.  (b) The people who might have liked this movie probably didn't go to see it, thinking it would be more of the same, which it isn't. <br /> <br />What I liked the most about this movie was that the big three (Harry, Hermione, and Ron) are given a chance to act--and they can act!  In the first two movies Ron especially was forced to do little more than scrunch up his face to look stunned, baffled, awed, scared, etc.  What a waste.  The quality of the acting from all three of the kids was very impressive--especially when you consider they were chosen initially because they \\"looked\\" like the characters in the books, and they could easily have all turned out to be duds, with absolutely no acting ability.  The fact that all three can act is nothing short of a miracle. <br /> <br />In several cases, I thought the screenplay was actually an improvement on the book.  This is heresy, I know.  But listen, in the movie, it's Hermione who realizes that they're to save Buckbeak--which makes much more sense and gives Hermione her due, while in the book it's Harry who makes the connection, something that is slightly out of character for him.  I also like the way that Hermione blows open Sirius's jail cell door near the end (girl power all the way, woohoo).  And the way that Harry overhears the conversation in the pub is much more believable in the film, as it makes use of the invisibility cloak, rather than on the fairly lame \\"move a tree in front of the table\\" ploy in the book. <br /> <br />The special effects are awesome, a big improvement especially over the first movie.  The scene where Harry rides Buckbeak is worth the price of admission all by itself.  The clocktower, bogart scenes, dementors, broomstick scenes, etc., are all done quite convincingly. <br /> <br />The scenery is spectacular and is used to good effect, with the talks between Harry and Prof. Lupin, especially, being done in places where there is very nice eye candy to look at in the background.   <br /> <br />There are also a lot of nice smaller touches, like the scene with the student choir singing \\"Something wicked this way comes.\\"  It's cute, but also adds a real touch of atmosphere.  The womping willow is used as a nice comic relief element, as are the shrunken heads.  (I could have done without the shrunken heads in the extra features part, where I felt it detracted from the otherwise very interesting interviews with the cast and crew.) <br /> <br />When I first watched the movie, I wasn't as impressed with it as I am now, after I've watched it half a dozen times at least.  For me, this movie has enough going on visually to give it quite a bit of replay value--and the eye candy is almost always left in the background so that it doesn't detract from the solid screenplay and the advancement of the storyline.   <br /> <br />I couldn't quite give this one five stars, but it's probably worth 4.5 when it comes right down to it.  Very solid, and certainly the best HP movie so far. <br />

B00004T8RK|5.0|Binaural (2000.), the Pearl Jam's sixth studio album<br /><br />The Pearl Jam were one of the great, if not the greatest rock acts of the 90's. From being part of the 'grunge' alternative rock explosion at first, the band were able to go off in their own direction by the end of the decade. By 2000, they were probably the only band from the grunge era to be still together, much to most people's amazement; not surprising, due to the band's withdrawal from the media spotlight. 'Binaural', the Pearl Jam's sixth studio album, released in 2000 is the capture of the great band entering the new millenium. 'Binaural' has proved to be the Pearl Jam's most criticised studio album, producing controversial opinions from reviewers and fans of the band alike. However, does this album really deserve its reputation as an ok but overly flat album?<br /><br />When I first bought 'Binaural', I was sceptical. I expected to like it but I reckoned that it wouldn't be in the league of 'Ten', 'Vs.', 'Yield' and 'No Code'. After a couple of listens to this album, I couldn't have been more wrong. 'Binaural' is one of those rare works, an album that sounds like no other, a disc that has a sound to it that's so unique whilst at the same time being unmistakably Pearl Jam. In fact, I would go as far to say that after 'Ten' and 'Yield', this album is next best in terms of greatness. Ok, the album overly lacks the aggression of 'Vs.' or the pure rockability of 'Yield' but it more than makes up for it in superb songwriting, diversity and atmospherics. That's not to say the album doesn't have its harder sometimes punk rocking moments like with 'Grievance' or 'Breakerfall' but on the whole the album is reflective and impacts on the senses in an undescribable fashion. Many people have dissed this album for the things I consider as plusses on the album. Many probably forget (non-fans who happen to own this album can be excused from this) that the Pearl Jam always look for a new direction every album and really this album, with its unique style, is one they had to make - fans especially must remember that this band have experimentation at their core. 'Binaural' is also the first Pearl Jam album to feature ex-Soundgarden drummer Matt Cameron, who replaced Jack Irons. Certainly a great addition to the band, some of the drumming, 'Grievance' is the song that comes to mind, is excellent. Furthermore, this is an album where the guitar work is much more subtle. McCready's guitar work may not be solo filled, but nevertheless the lower key but certainly adept guitar work works well with the album's style.<br /><br />To get things rolling, the album begins in rocking fashion, with the short 'Breakerfall'. The influence of the Who is definitely here in this one and that's no bad thing in this powered opener. Following this is another short song, the punk rocking 'God's Dice'. On a first listen this song didn't really do it for me, but over time I've appreciated it more; not quite classic Pearl Jam but I'll take it nonetheless! However, next up is a great song in 'Evacuation'. I found this one quite catchy; the drumming is powerful and this backdrops well to Vedder's howling chorus. Then we come to the longer more thoughtful stuff. 'Light Years' is a heartfelt lyrical offering from Vedder with some great but subtle guitar play. Similarly, the thoughtful theme continues with 'Nothing As It Seems', a more downbeat sounding song but with more atmospheric moments. 'Thin Air' is an acoustic gem with some more great lyrics and 'Insignificance', next up, has some sombre but compelling guitar melodies, and a superb crashing chorus. After this impressive passage, things get even better with the beautifully complex 'Of The Girl' with more hushed but striking vocals from Eddie Vedder and some luscious guitar work. Following this is the Grammy-nominated 'Grievance', a stunning track to say the least both lyrically and instrumentally. The pace of the track changes a few times but it worksmagnificently, especially where the drumming is concerned; a great protest song that only Vedder himself could pen. 'Rival' follows this; a step down from previous songs but still a good song, with an interesting growling dog opening. Then we have 'Sleight Of Hand', slow but atmospheric; a classic that builds but to great climax. 'Soon Forget' is an interesting interlude consisiting of Eddie Vedder and a ukelele. Its a poetic ramble that draws comparisons with The Who song 'Blue, Red and Grey'; again though I have no problems with the Pearl Jam being influenced by The Who. Then, to finish this great album we have the emotionally moving and striking 'Parting Ways'. Vedder's vocals are at their most reflective here and the song exit, using guitar and violins/cellos is heart-rendering.<br /><br />If you had to take the two albums which the Pearl Jam have made which have a difference of opinion right down the middle between fans, you have 'Vitalogy' and 'Binaural'. With the former I was on the sceptical side, enjoying a fair share of the album but being left disappointed by some moments, however with 'Binaural' I'm firmly in the positive. This album is a mellow but atmospheric and compelling stroke of genius. Eventhough this is up there with the best (in my opinion), I wouldn't recommend this album to a newbie to the Pearl Jam - that's what 'Yield' is for. However, any fan who appreciates the Pearl Jam's evolvoing and experimental edge should enjoy this album and appreciate its greatness. I'll not doubt that it needs a few listens to get into but nevertheless it is one hell of a masterpiece, just sadly an album that has become underrated and bashed by critics.lly where the drumming is concerned; a great protest song that only Vedder himself could pen. 'Rival' follows this; a step down from previous songs but still a good song, with an interesting growling dog opening. Then we have 'Sleight Of Hand', slow but atmospheric; a classic that builds but to great climax. 'Soon Forget' is an interesting interlude consisiting of Eddie Vedder and a ukelele. Its a poetic ramble that draws comparisons with The Who song 'Blue, Red and Grey'; again though I have no problems with the Pearl Jam being influenced by The Who. Then, to finish this great album we have the emotionally moving and striking 'Parting Ways'. Vedder's vocals are at their most reflective here and the song exit, using guitar and violins/cellos is heart-rendering.    If you had to take the two albums which the Pearl Jam have made which have a difference of opinion right down the middle between fans, you have 'Vitalogy' and 'Binaural'. With the former I was on the sceptical side, enjoying a fair share of the album but being left disappointed by some moments, however with 'Binaural' I'm firmly in the positive. This album is a mellow but atmospheric and compelling stroke of genius. Eventhough this is up there with the best (in my opinion), I wouldn't recommend this album to a newbie to the Pearl Jam - that's what 'Yield' is for. However, any fan who appreciates the Pearl Jam's evolvoing and experimental edge should enjoy this album and appreciate its greatness. I'll not doubt that it needs a few listens to get into but nevertheless it is one hell of a masterpiece, just sadly an album that has become underrated and bashed by critics.
B000B5XOSO|4.0|If you love Tim Burton, you'll love this movie. If you don't like him, you'll probably hate it. That's because this is one of the few movies in Burton's career where he had absolute, total controll over what happened, a decision WB came to regret when idiot parents brought their babies to a movie about a deformed maniac who lives in the sewer and complained.  <br />The movie still did fine, over $160 million in its time. Adjusted, that's still well over what Batman Begins made, although far under Batman's (1989) gross of $250 million. <br /> <br />This is not an action movie, but rather a dark fary-tale based on Batman characters. The Penguin is an absolute twisted delight as The Penguin, although some fans gripe that his orgin was changed from the Comic Books (as if the Comic Book characters aren't constantly changing, themselves!). He's funny and creepy, and Michelle Pfiefer is nearly as good as Catwoman. <br />Christopher Walken is a third wheel on a villainous bike, and his part could have been done without. It is interesting to note that his character was originally Harvey Dent, to be played by Billy-Dee Williams, and would have become Two-Face at the end of the movie. Batman takes a back seat to the villains in this particular chapter, but Michael Keaton is still very convincing.  <br />With a bigger budget, Burton was allowed even more beautiful visuals. Gotham City never looked better (and never looked as good again, with the exception of Batman: The Animated Series) as it does in its Art Deco, timeless form here. <br /> <br />The movie is far from perfect, but definitely worth trying. Some people can't stand its abandon, imagination, and inventiveness, and prefer a more realistic version of the character, which they got in Batman Begins. But Tim Burton's version of the character will always be one of my favorite interpretations.

B00008BLB8|2.0|Late '60s, early '70s band from Flint, Michigan came up from the ranks of self promotion and constant touring to establish themselves as America's favorite hard rock party band. So with Grand Funk classics like the hard rock bluesy \\"Heartbreaker\\", would be prog pretty, \\"Closer To Home\\", and later successful hits like the airplay aplenty, \\"Some Kind Of Wonderful\\", and the Little Eva remake, \\"Loco-Motion\\", why does this live recording from 1975 sound as lifeless as a dormant railroad track, and as tiring as an after-party Tylenol? Could be that the band was losing it's appeal as their total output proved the party was chaperoned by a desperate attempt to remain on track with super produced hit singles rendering the band's original American sound anonymous. The uninspired drum solo is here as is an indifferent three minute treatment of the Todd Rundgren produced big hit single, \\"We're An American Band\\", which the band merely checks off their song list, as if impatient to get it out of the way, while \\"The Railroad\\" offers a gentler and heavier Grand Funk as a hard working class blues oriented rock band. The earlier \\"Grand Funk Live Album\\" is the one to get, showcasing this suburban teenage no-future spirit before the spoils of success.

B00005JNQA|3.0|\\"The interpreter\\", directed by Sydney Pollack, is a thriller that deals with a plot to kill Zuwanie (Earl Cameron), the dictator of Motobo (a fictional African country) in front of the United Nations' General Assembly. The pace is quick, the general premise interesting, and the actors excellent, but in the end the movie is just good, not great.<br /><br />The main character is Silvia Broome (Nicole Kidman), an interpreter working for the United Nations, who lived a long time in Motobo. One day, Silvia returns to the interpreters' booth in order collect some things she forgot, and by chance hears some conspirators whispering in Ku (the language of Motobo) about a plan to kill Zuwanie. Unfortunately for Silvia, they see her, but she manages to escape. The following day, Silvia goes to the police to tell them what she heard. The problem is, they are not totally sure they believe her. And as events develop, one of the officers in charge of protecting visiting dignitaries, a very troubled Tobin Keller (Sean Penn), begins to suspects that Silvia has more reasons that anyone else to kill Zuwabi. In the end, it is difficult to know who is lying, and why.<br /><br />The ending is somewhat surprising, but it feels a little contrived. Also, there are hints throughout the movie of an emotional connections of sorts forming between Silvia and Tobin, but nothings gets round to happening, and some spectators will end up saying aloud \\"Is that all?\\" at the end of the movie. At least, that is what happened to me.<br /><br />Notwithstanding that, I would like to point that I specially enjoyed two of the extra features included in the dvd, \\"The Ultimate Movie Set: The United Nations\\" and \\"A Day in the Life of Real Interpreters\\". My favorite was the first one, in which the director and part of the crew talk about the process of gaining permission to shoot in the building, and what it meant for them to get it, turning \\"The interpreter\\" into the first film to be shot inside the United Nations Headquarters. That feature also shows extra shoots of the building, the General Assembly and the room where the public sessions of the Security Council are held (depending on the issue, there are also private meetings not open to the public).<br /><br />On the whole, and despite the excellent acting, I think that this movie was no more than adequate. Truth to be told, the thing I'll probably remember more about \\"The interpreter\\" is its set, that is, the United Nations' building. But... I believe that something is wrong with a film when the most noteworthy feature is the setting.<br /><br />Belen Alcateature also shows extra shoots of the building, the General Assembly and the room where the public sessions of the Security Council are held (depending on the issue, there are also private meetings not open to the public). I believe that something is wrong with a film when the most noteworthy feature is the setting.    Belen Alcat

0312954468|4.0|About halfway through RIVER GOD, a highly-entertaining novel full of intrigue and detail about how ancient Egyptians thought and lived, I got that sensation of Deja Vu.  Some time ago, I'd read a novel about the life of Hatshepsut, the early woman Pharoah of Egypt, c. 15th Century B.C.  I realized the events concerning the main characters were playing out just as they did in that novel, though the background of the lovely young woman, Lostris, here destined to wed the Pharoah Mamose, despite her love for the young warrior, Tanus, differed from the earlier book I read, in which the future Hatshepsut was the sister of the future Pharaoh.  In each case, however, the heroine bears a child to the warrior, who is believed to be the child of the rightful king, and becomes his heir.  She is then regent while the boy grows up, Pharaoh while the Egyptian dynasty is driven into exile far south down the Nile due to the Hyksos conquest of Upper and Lower Egypt.  By the time the Hyksos with their horses and chariots make mincemeat of the Egyptian army, who have never before seen either wheels or horses, I realized it was much the same plot as the other book. Another key event was identical, involving the disgrace of Intef, the king's vizier, and the manner of discovery of proof of his embezzlement of riches belonging to the Pharaoh. The other book was nowhere near as entertaining, but I wish a reader who picked up the book had been given some clue Wilbur Smith was retelling a story based on the life of Hatshepsut.  She was a real ruler, there is a temple to her in Egypt, etc. History can't be copyrighted, and the story certainly must have been out by any definition of the public domain for thousands of years, but it has spoiled my eager page-turning to realize in advance exactly where this story is headed.  Had I seen some reference to this on the cover or in the reviews, I wouldn't have felt so disappointed, as Wilbur Smith's presentation is so lively and fresh.  As it was, I believed I was reading something entirely...well...new.  Having recently visited the King Tut exhibition in Los Angeles, I realize not a whole lot is actually certain about what archeology knows about much of Egyptian history, who fathered who, etc.  This despite exhaustive excavation and study over more than the last century.  So maybe the events in Hatshepsut's story are based on myth Smith felt free to borrow from, just as perhaps the other author did.  Still, I think it would only have been fair for Smith to give the reader a clue as to the tale the novel  was based on, as his afterward does not mention it either.  Sigh.  Taita was a fascinating if ridiculously gifted narrator, a slave who, to hear him tell it, was in one lifetime responsible for every advancement of science, medicine, art and technology developed in ancient Egypt--a tall order for most readers to swallow, just as it would have been to accomplish. <br />Still Smith is a lively storyteller, and the reader who is new to this legend will thoroughly enjoy it.

B000003TAR|4.0|Kurt Cobain's life in 1993 was about as bleak and stressful as they come: His heroin addiction was crippling him, his relationship with his evil b*tch of a wife was dissipating, and he had the unpleasant task of lugging around his band's superstar status. Playing sold-out stadiums filled with idiotic MTV-whores sure wasn't as fun as the small clubs and punk shows back home in Aberdeen, now was it?<br /><br />Right from the opening lyric of \\"Serve The Servants\\" (teenage angst has paid off well), it's obvious that this is something different: By cutting down on the too-clean production and blantant Pixies worship that plagued many of the songs on \\"Nevermind\\", they created \\"In Utero\\", the best album of their career. The shiny, catchy hard-rock is replaced with a stark \\"setting sun on the last day of your life\\" feel, courtesy of the great Steve Albini's production. Even the 'catchy' songs are grim and foreboding. Make no mistake: this isn't exactly music for cruising down the highway in your '67 Mustang with your buds.<br /><br />On the lone single \\"Heart-Shaped Box\\", you can actually feel the instruments emitting a sense of defeat as Kurt's downbeat guitar riff and sighing voice shuffle onward, into a drum-heavy chorus. \\"All Apologies\\" follows a similar strategy, but this time, it sounds more like a deathblow than a cry for help. Perhaps \\"Rape Me\\" and \\"Milk It\\" are responses to the money-hungry music industry, trying to give the jocks and preps as much exposure to Nirvana as possible. That's at least how I picture it.<br /><br />Although not without it's flaws (several of the later tracks are blurbs that are too short and undeveloped to be considered of much use), this depressing, difficult path is definitely what suited Nirvana the most. Play it on those days when life feels like a hopeless blur. Knowing Kurt's right there beside you is strangely life-affirming.<br /><br />There isn't a doubt in my mind that Courtney Love murdered Kurt (as well as the absolutely beautiful Kristen Pfaff), or that Kurt was showing huge signs of improvement at the time of his death, but \\"In Utero\\" shows that the struggles he faced a few months prior to his demise were real. It's not like anyone else could successfully replicate that formula either: That's why KoRn and Papa Roach, bands that thrive primarily on a fake version of the angst Nirvana displays here, couldn't write a good song to save their lives.<br /><br />Reccommended.ly beautiful Kristen Pfaff), or that Kurt was showing huge signs of improvement at the time of his death, but \\"In Utero\\" shows that the struggles he faced a few months prior to his demise were real. B00008LOS1|5.0|Who's Next is the greatest of the Who's studio releases.  It was truely an album unlike any other in that it was put together like Frankenstein; songs from different origins and parts of Townshend's post-Tommy project, Lifehouse.  The album is composed of recorded, cut, re-recorded, and fine-tuned Lifehouse songs, and one non-Lifehouse song, John Entwistle's dark-humored \\"My Wife\\".  Of all Who albums, the most lasting Who anthems come from Who's Next; the masterful \\"Baba O'Riley\\" (Teenage Wasteland), \\"Bargain\\", the raging \\"Behind Blue Eyes\\", and the musical juggernaut that is \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\".  Although the Lifehouse project was scraped, its soul lives in Who's Next, even more so with this Deluxe Edition, which includes most of the cut Lifehouse songs, not released on the original album in 1971.  Most importantly, \\"Pure & Easy\\", an expression of earlier musical simlpicity, \\"Time Is Passing\\", \\"Too Much of Anything\\", and the alternate versions of \\"Love Ain't For Keeping\\", \\"Getting In Tune\\", \\"Behind Blue Eyes\\", and \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\".  The second CD is composed of the Who's April 26th, 1971 Lifehouse performance at The Young Vic Theatre in London, England.  The album only lacks three of the songs performed by the Who that night; Pinball Wizard, See Me, Feel Me, and Bony Moronie.  For the interested, the performance of \\"Bony Maronie\\" from the Young Vic is included on the \\"30 Years of Maximum R&B\\" box set, but sadly, the remaining two songs, taken from Tommy, have never been released on an offical Who record, but is available on the bootleg, \\"Young Vic Blues\\", along with other excepts from the Young Vic Concert.  Overall, this is an essential not just for Who fans, but for any person who has ever listened to a Rock song.  Who's Next defines the bridge between the music of the 1960's and the '70's and beyond.

B000002P2W|5.0|The Who By Numbers is an album different from other Who albums.  It is an expression of the angst and inner-feelings of these four aging rockers.  Pete Townshend writes some of his most honest music for this album.  The mellow \\"Blue, Red, and Grey\\" is as far from an rock song ever produced, it rips the seams of the canvas that shielded Pete's true feelings from the world.  Pete and the Who express their questions as to their fame and rock status through songs like \\"How Many Friends\\", \\"They Are All In Love\\", and \\"However Much I Booze\\".  John Entwistle contributes his usual dark humor through his song, \\"Success Story\\".  Keith does some of his best drumming on the album in \\"Dreaming From The Waist\\".  Although The Who are a rock band, this isn't a true rock album, but, nevertheless, a important album to hear to truely understand the previous and following Who albums and the band members themselves.  At it's time of release in 1975, many music critics called it \\"A Suicide Note\\", as it was a 180 Degree turn from the previous Who album, Quadrophenia.  As always, first impressions and opinions aren't always correct; The Who By Numbers now stands as one of greatest look into the live of a rock group.  It is an essential to any Who or Rock fan.
B0000256KE|5.0|Every album Roxy did in the early seventies is very good. Unconventional and different sounding even today this is the one that everyone who thinks all rock music sounds the same should own.  Every song is a winner and there is not a weak minute contained.  It should contain a warning to beware of solo breaks, they are brutal.
B000002P2V|3.0|Who Are You is much different from any other previous Who album in that it's musical composition was more synthesiers than guitar, drums, and bass.  Originally released in 1978, Who Are You is composed of mostly songs that are statements of Pete Townshend; his dislike of the Disco genre (Sister Disco), Musical Composition (Guitar and Pen), and an encounter with an up and coming Punk group, The Sex Pistols, in \\"Who Are You\\", the title track.  Although any Who fan, and most rock fans, are extremely familiar with \\"Who Are You\\", as it is a solid rock anthem, most of the other tracks have been lost behind earlier Who works, such as Who's Next and Tommy.  Unlike other albums, John Entwistle has more of his compositions on Who Are You.  A lack-luster \\"Had Enough\\", a curious look at cloning (905), and \\"Trick of the Light\\".  Who Are You was the last decent Who Studio Album, as Keith Moon died shortly after the album was produced, of an accidental overdose on the medicine prescripted to him to combat his extreme alcoholism.  A very little know fact is that although Keith Moon died shortly after the album was produced, he did play \\"Who Are You\\" live, twice.  The two concerts occurred in Toronto on October 21st, 1976, and the later was the dismal Kilburn Gamount State Concert in 1977, which was setup to produce live performances for \\"The Kids Are Alright\\".  Overall, this album is last studio stand for the Who, before the \\"Kenney Jones Years\\".  If you are a Who fan, buy this album not just for the title track, but for the attempted Punk / Hard Rock Conversion it attempted.

B000002UAO|5.0|Although it's not as lauded as later albums, \\"Rubber Soul\\" marks a huge step forward for The Beatles in terms of maturity. Mainly, the lyrical content is more serious. There's still a lot of songs dealing with relationships, but they're delivered in a more mature, introspective way. There's definetly a ton of Bob Dylan influence on this album, as they delve deep into a more folky, artsy sound on many songs. <br /> <br />Paul McCartney's tuneful \\"Drive My Car\\" is a buoyant, can't miss opener with a deliciously catchy chorus. It suggests that \\"Rubber Soul\\" may be a pretty breezy, upbeat album..then, Lennon delivers \\"Norwegian Wood\\", a cryptic folk song which features George Harrison on sitar, giving it a slight indian feel as well.  <br /> <br />However, both Paul and John (and George to a lesser extent at this point) are masters at creating intriguing, catchy melodies in their songs. So stuff that may sound weird on paper still comes across as highly melodic pop. For instance, Lennon's gorgeous, melancholy \\"Nowhere Man\\".  <br /> <br />\\"Nowhere Man\\" isn't Lennon's only downbeat gem on here. He also turns in one of his best songs of all time (if not *the* best) with \\"In My Life\\". The fact that he's dead adds even more weight and emotion to the song. Everything from the verses to the harmonies to George Martin's piano solo in the middle is just perfect. <br /> <br />For the most part, Paul's songs sound much more upbeat (which was the case for all the Beatles albums). \\"If I Needed Someone\\" and \\"I'm Looking Through You\\" are both blissfully perfect pop songs, with a shimmering, jangly feel throughout. Very Byrds-y. <br /> <br />He also turns in a minor key gem with \\"Michelle\\", as does John Lennon with \\"Girl\\". These lush, intricate melodies are far removed from what The Beatles were doing even a year prior to this.  <br /> <br />Other highlights include the anthematic \\"The Word\\", George Harrison's folksy \\"If I Needed Someone\\" (which also recalls The Byrds), the urgent \\"Wait\\", and the country-ish \\"What Goes On\\", in which Ringo Starr takes lead vocals. <br /> <br />Maybe not as mindblowing as \\"Revolver\\" or \\"Sgt. Pepper\\", but \\"Rubber Soul\\" is just as essential.

Then the singles, including Silver Springs, were all over the radio and it was played to death. Today the guitars, the rythym section, and the vocals blend together even better than yesterday. The internal turmoil of the band produced some of the most wonderful, angry and hurt songs ever recorded. I know this all seems to be pretty convoluted but I guess you have to have lived, loved, and been thrown away to appreciate it all.
1577312082|5.0|Although I have not read the book and have only heard the audio version, I can imagine that the book might seem repetitive. The audio version is stunning. It does not seem repetitive in the least, but nuanced and thorough in its elucidation of the unique state of presence. It is apparent that he speaks from what he knows intimately.
